"Medical Report
Patient Information: 
• Name: Sarah Taylor
• Address: 789 Oakwood Lane Suite 303
Springfield, IL 62701, Tuvalu
• Date of Birth: March 12, 1985
• ID Number: 384501923
• Insurance Number: HJFOWE82S017
• Email: staylor@example.com
• Credit Card Number: 4532-7810-5643-9087
Date of Consultation: October 29, 2022

Chief Complaint: The patient presents with complaints of persistent lower back pain and numbness in the legs over the past two weeks.

History of Present Illness: Ms. Taylor reports experiencing constant lower back pain, radiating down her left leg, accompanied by numbness and tingling sensations. She notes that the symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past fortnight and are now affecting her mobility and quality of life.

Past Medical History:

Osteoporosis, diagnosed 3 years ago.

Type 2 diabetes, managed with oral medications.

Previous cholecystectomy for gallstones.

Family History:

Father alive, with a history of hypertension and stroke.

Mother deceased due to breast cancer at age 50.

Two siblings, both in good health.

Social History: Ms. Taylor is a retired teacher and reports a moderately active lifestyle. She denies tobacco or recreational drug use. She consumes alcohol occasionally, socially.

Review of Systems:

Cardiovascular: No chest pain or palpitations.

Respiratory: No cough or shortness of breath.

Gastrointestinal: No recent abdominal discomfort or changes in bowel habits.

Neurological: Lower back pain and numbness as described above.

Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or swelling.

Dermatological: No rashes or lesions.

Physical Examination:

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 140/85 mmHg, pulse 78 bpm, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 98.4°F.

General: Alert and oriented x3, mild discomfort noted during movement.

Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic.

Eyes: Pupils equal and reactive to light, no visual disturbances noted.

Ears, Nose, Throat: Tympanic membranes clear, no nasal congestion.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.

Neurological: Decreased sensation and diminished reflexes in the left lower extremity.

Assessment and Plan:

Differential diagnosis for Ms. Taylor's lower back pain and leg numbness includes lumbar disc herniation, spinal stenosis, and diabetic neuropathy. Further evaluation with lumbar spine imaging may be warranted.

Management of diabetes to optimize blood glucose control.

Symptomatic relief with NSAIDs for pain management.

Referral to physical therapy for strengthening exercises and mobility improvement.

Follow-up appointment scheduled in three weeks to assess response to treatment and consider additional interventions as necessary.

Follow-up Instructions:

Ms. Taylor is advised to avoid prolonged sitting or standing and to use proper body mechanics to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

She is counseled on the importance of maintaining good glycemic control through diet and medication adherence.

Dr. Michael Williams M.D.
Board Certified Physician
St. Luke's Hospital

Chief Complaint: The patient presents with complaints of persistent abdominal pain and bloating for the past month.

History of Present Illness: Mrs. Rodriguez reports experiencing recurrent abdominal pain, primarily in the epigastric region, associated with bloating and occasional nausea. She notes that the symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past month and are now impacting her appetite and overall well-being.

Past Medical History:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), diagnosed 2 years ago.

Hypothyroidism, managed with levothyroxine.

Previous appendectomy for acute appendicitis.

Family History:

Father alive, with a history of coronary artery disease.

Mother deceased due to pancreatic cancer at age 65.

One sibling with a history of asthma.

Social History: Mrs. Rodriguez is a homemaker and reports a sedentary lifestyle. She denies tobacco or recreational drug use. She consumes alcohol occasionally, socially.

Review of Systems:

Cardiovascular: No chest pain or palpitations.

Respiratory: No cough or shortness of breath.

Gastrointestinal: Abdominal pain and bloating as described above.

Neurological: No headaches, dizziness, or weakness.

Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or swelling.

Dermatological: No rashes or lesions.

Physical Examination:

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 120/75 mmHg, pulse 70 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 98.7°F.

General: Alert and oriented x3, no acute distress.

Head: Normocephalic, atraumatic.

Eyes: Pupils equal and reactive to light, no scleral icterus.

Ears, Nose, Throat: Tympanic membranes clear, no signs of oral lesions.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, mildly distended with hypoactive bowel sounds.

Neurological: Cranial nerves intact, no focal deficits.

Assessment and Plan:

Differential diagnosis for Mrs. Rodriguez's abdominal pain and bloating includes gastroenteritis, peptic ulcer disease, and irritable bowel syndrome. Further evaluation with abdominal imaging and laboratory tests may be warranted.

Management of GERD with lifestyle modifications and proton pump inhibitors as needed.

Symptomatic relief with antispasmodic medications for abdominal discomfort.

Dietary counseling to avoid trigger foods and promote regular meals.

Follow-up appointment scheduled in four weeks to assess response to treatment and consider additional interventions as necessary.

Follow-up Instructions:

Mrs. Rodriguez is advised to maintain a food diary to identify potential trigger foods for her symptoms.

She is counseled on stress reduction techniques and encouraged to incorporate regular physical activity into her daily routine.

Dr. Courtney Lee, M.D.
Board Certified Physician
Mercy Hospital

Greenwood Clinic

Assessment and Plan:

Differential diagnosis for Ms. White's shortness of breath and wheezing includes asthma exacerbation, allergic rhinitis, and bronchitis. Further evaluation with pulmonary function tests and allergy testing may be warranted.

Environmental control measures to minimize exposure to allergens.

Ms. White is advised to avoid triggers such as dust, pollen, and pet dander.

She is counseled on proper inhaler technique and encouraged to carry a rescue inhaler at all times.

Dr. James Harden, M.D.
Board Certified Physician
Maplewood Medical Center
